title: 18th King Edward's Own Cavalry
text:
The 18th King Edward's Own Cavalry was a regular <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> regiment in the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a>. Following the <a href="Indian%20independence%20movement">independence of India</a>, the regiment was allotted to the Indian Army and redesignated as the 18th Cavalry.
Formation.
Tracing its origins from 1842, the regiment was formed in 1921 by the amalgamation of the <a href="6th%20King%20Edward%27s%20Own%20Cavalry">6th King Edward's Own Cavalry</a> and the <a href="7th%20Hariana%20Lancers">7th Hariana Lancers</a>. These two regiments too had undergone many changes – 
The composition of the regiment at the time of amalgamation was <a href="Qaimkhani">Kaimkhanis</a>, <a href="Rajputana">Rajputana</a> <a href="Rajput">Rajput</a>s and <a href="Jat%20people">Jats</a>. The present class composition is of Jats from <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="Haryana">Haryana</a> and <a href="Rajasthan">Rajasthan</a>; Rajputs from Uttar Pradesh, <a href="Madhya%20Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a> and Rajasthan and Hindustani Mussalmans from all over India, but mainly from Uttar Pradesh and <a href="West%20Bengal">West Bengal</a>.
Operations during the British Raj.
Second World War.
In December 1940, during the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>, the regiment was mechanized. It formed part of the <a href="3rd%20Indian%20Motor%20Brigade">3rd Indian Motor Brigade</a>, which was initially part of the <a href="31st%20Indian%20Armoured%20Division">1st Indian Armoured Division</a>.
The brigade was detached from the division, and dispatched to <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> along with its units including the 18th King Edward's Own Cavalry. The regiment then served in the <a href="Western%20Desert%20campaign">Western Desert campaign</a>. The regiment, and the brigade, were attached to a number of different formations that included the <a href="2nd%20Armoured%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">2nd Armoured Division</a>, the <a href="7th%20Armoured%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">7th Armoured Division</a>, and the <a href="9th%20Australian%20Division">9th Australian Division</a> who they were with during the <a href="Siege%20of%20Tobruk">Siege of Tobruk</a>. The regiment also supplied men for the <a href="Indian%20Long%20Range%20Squadron">Indian Long Range Squadron</a>. The brigade was later overrun by the Italians during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Gazala">Battle of Gazala</a>, and took some days to reform. After the brigade reformed, the regiment was equipped as follows: Cavalry Carrier - 2 x Reconnaissance Squadron, 1 x AT Squadron.
On 30 June, the brigade was ordered to hand over 50 per cent of its vehicles to the Eighth Army, and was dispersed and the regiment was allotted to the defence of the Nile Delta and guard duties. In August, the brigade reformed and was allocated the regiment. It travelled overland to Sahneh, in Persia via Baghdad, and was placed under the command of the 31st Indian Armoured Division (formally the 1st Indian Armoured Division). In late November it then moved to <a href="Shaibah">Shaibah</a>, from Basra. From here the regiment returned to India in January 1943, and the brigade was reconstituted as the <a href="43rd%20Independent%20Gurkha%20Infantry%20Brigade">43rd Indian Infantry Brigade (Lorried)</a> at Shaibah at the end of January 1943. In the middle of the year, it moved to Rawalpindi and commenced conversion to a light cruiser regiment. By the end of the year, the regiment successfully converted into a light cruiser tank regiment. The regiment was split up after that, serving in different parts of India when the Japanese surrender came in August 1945.
18th King Edward's Own Cavalry won the following gallantry awards during the Second World War -
Operations in independent India.
Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.
During the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201965">Indo-Pakistani War of 1965</a>, the regiment fought a series of isolated armour battles as part of the <a href="1st%20Armoured%20Division%20%28India%29">1st Armoured Division</a> in the approaches to <a href="Sialkot">Sialkot</a>. They left behind 29 destroyed enemy tanks and Naib Risaldar <a href="Mohd.%20Ayub%20Khan">Mohd. Ayub Khan</a> was awarded the <a href="Vir%20Chakra">Vir Chakra</a>. 7 were mentioned in despatches.
Indo-Pakistani War of 1971.
During the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201971">Indo-Pakistani War of 1971</a>, the regiment saw action in the <a href="Fazilka">Fazilka</a> sector. Naib Risaldar Noor Mohammed Khan was awarded the Vir Charkra.
Other operations.
The regiment has participated in <a href="Kargil%20War">Operation Vijay</a>, <a href="2001%E2%80%932002%20India%E2%80%93Pakistan%20standoff">Operation Parakram</a> and undertaken counter insurgency operations in <a href="Jammu%20and%20Kashmir%20%28state%29">Jammu and Kashmir</a>, where it was awarded the <a href="Northern%20Command%20%28India%29">GOC-in-C (Northern Command)</a> Unit Citation.
Battle honours.
The regiment was awarded the following <a href="battle%20honours">battle honours</a>:
<a href="Punniar">Punniar</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Mudki">Moodkee</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Ferozeshah">Ferozeshah</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Sobraon">Sobraon</a>, <a href="Egypt%201882">Egypt 1882</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Tel%20el-Kebir">Tel-el-Kebir</a>, Punjab Frontier
<a href="Second%20Anglo-Sikh%20War">Punjaub</a>, <a href="Burma%201885%E2%80%9387">Burma 1885–87</a>
"Awarded in 1926 for services of predecessor regiments"<br>
<a href="Somme%201916">Somme 1916</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Morval">Morval</a>, <a href="Cambrai%201917">Cambrai 1917</a>, <a href="France%20and%20Flanders%201914%E2%80%9318">France and Flanders 1914–18</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Megiddo%20%281918%29">Megiddo</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Sharon">Sharon</a>, <a href="Capture%20of%20Damascus%20%281918%29">Damascus</a>, <a href="Palestine%201918">Palestine 1918</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Shaiba">Shaiba</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Es%20Sinn">Kut-al-Amara 1915</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Ctesiphon%20%281915%29">Ctesiphon</a>, <a href="Tigris%201916">Tigris 1916</a>, <a href="Mesopotamia%201915%E2%80%9316">Mesopotamia 1915–16</a>
<a href="Mechili%23History">El Mechili</a>, <a href="Siege%20of%20Tobruk">Defence of Tobruk</a>, <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20El%20Alamein%23Retreat%20from%20Gazala">The Kennels</a>, <a href="North%20Africa%201940%E2%80%9343">North Africa 1940–43</a>
<a href="Battle%20and%20theatre%20honours%20of%20the%20Indian%20Army%23Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201965">Jammu and Kashmir 1965</a>, <a href="Battle%20and%20theatre%20honours%20of%20the%20Indian%20Army%23Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201965">Tilkapur-Muhadipur</a>, <a href="Battle%20and%20theatre%20honours%20of%20the%20Indian%20Army%23Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201965">Punjab 1965</a>
President’s Standards.
The <a href="President%20of%20India">President of India</a>, <a href="Neelam%20Sanjiva%20Reddy">Neelam Sanjiva Reddy</a> presented a <a href="Guidon%20%28Commonwealth%29">guidon</a> to the regiment at <a href="Amritsar">Amritsar</a> on 26 March 1980.
The Regiment was presented the ‘<a href="President%27s%20Colour%20Award">President’s Standards</a>’ at Amritsar on 7 March 2016 by General <a href="Dalbir%20Singh%20Suhag">Dalbir Singh</a>, <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20Army%20Staff%20%28India%29">Chief of the Army Staff</a>, on behalf of the President of India, Mr <a href="Pranab%20Mukherjee">Pranab Mukherjee</a>.
Equipment.
The regiment shed its horses and was converted to a motorised cavalry regiment equipped with anti-tank guns in 1940. This gave way to tanks in 1943 with the introduction of the <a href="M3%20Stuart">Stuart tanks</a>. They were succeeded by the <a href="M4%20Sherman">Sherman tanks</a> in 1946, the <a href="T-54/T-55">T-54</a>s in 1966 and finally the <a href="T-72">T-72</a>s in 1983.
Regimental Insiginia.
The Regimental insignia consists of crossed <a href="lance">lance</a>s with <a href="pennon">pennon</a>s. Each of the pennons have scrolls with the words सत्यमेव (Satyameva) and जयते (Jayate). Satyameva Jayate translates to ‘Truth alone triumphs’. Th crossed lances are overlaid with the numeral "18" mounted by the <a href="State%20Emblem%20of%20India">Ashoka Lion Capital</a> and a scroll at the base with the words ‘Cavalry’.
The motto of the regiment is साहस और सम्मान (Saahas Aur Samman), which translates to ‘Courage and honour’.
